xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: CIS Oracle Database 12c Benchmark

xhtml:h4.xhtml:strong: This is the archive of the CIS Benchmark for Oracle Database 12c. CIS encourages you to migrate to a more recent, supported version of this technology.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This document is intended to address the recommended security settings for Oracle Database 12c. This guide was tested against Oracle Database 12c (version 12.1.0.2) installed without pluggable database support running on a Windows Server 2012 R2 instance as a stand-alone system and running on an Oracle Linux 7 instance also as a stand-alone system. Future Oracle Database 12c critical patch updates (CPUs) may impact the recommendations included in this document.

To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org
. If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org
.

xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:notice: BACKGROUND. The Center for Internet Security ("CIS") provides benchmarks, scoring tools, software, data, information, suggestions, ideas, and other services and materials from the CIS website or elsewhere ("Products") as a public service to Internet users worldwide. Recommendations contained in the Products ("Recommendations") result from a consensus-building process that involves many security experts and are generally generic in nature. The Recommendations are intended to provide helpful information to organizations attempting to evaluate or improve the security of their networks, systems, and devices. Proper use of the Recommendations requires careful analysis and adaptation to specific user requirements. The Recommendations are not in any way intended to be a "quick fix" for anyone's information security needs. NO REPRESENTATIONS, WARRANTIES, OR COVENANTS. CIS makes no representations, warranties, or covenants whatsoever as to (i) the positive or negative effect of the Products or the Recommendations on the operation or the security of any particular network, computer system, network device, software, hardware, or any component of any of the foregoing or (ii) the accuracy, reliability, timeliness, or completeness of the Products or the Recommendations. CIS is providing the Products and the Recommendations "as is" and "as available" without representations, warranties, or covenants of any kind. USER AGREEMENTS. By using the Products and/or the Recommendations, I and/or my organization ("We") agree and acknowledge that: 1. No network, system, device, hardware, software, or component can be made fully secure; 2. We are using the Products and the Recommendations solely at our own risk; 3. We are not compensating CIS to assume any liabilities associated with our use of the Products or the Recommendations, even risks that result from CIS's negligence or failure to perform; 4. We have the sole responsibility to evaluate the risks and benefits of the Products and Recommendations to us and to adapt the Products and the Recommendations to our particular circumstances and requirements; 5. Neither CIS, nor any CIS Party (defined below) has any responsibility to make any corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; or to notify us of the need for any such corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; and 6. Neither CIS nor any CIS Party has or will have any liability to us whatsoever (whether based in contract, tort, strict liability or otherwise) for any direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, or special damages (including without limitation loss of profits, loss of sales, loss of or damage to reputation,loss of customers, loss of software, data, information or emails, loss of privacy, loss of use of any computer or other equipment, business interruption, wasted management or other staff resources or claims of any kind against us from third parties) arising out of or in any way Connected with our use of or our inability to use any of the Products or Recommendations (even if CIS has been advised of the possibility of such damages), including without limitation any liability associated with infringement of intellectual property, defects, bugs, errors, omissions, viruses, worms, backdoors, Trojan horses or other harmful items. GRANT OF LIMITED RIGHTS. CIS hereby grants each user the following rights, but only so long as the user complies with all of the terms of these Agreed Terms of Use: 1. Except to the extent that we may have received additional authorization pursuant to a written agreement with CIS, each user may download, install and use each of the Products on a single computer; 2. Each user may print one or more copies of any Product or any component of a Product that is in a .txt, .pdf, .doc, .mcw, or .rtf format, provided that all such copies are printed in full and are kept intact, including without limitation the text of this Agreed Terms of Use in its entirety. RETENTION OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS; LIMITATIONS ON DISTRIBUTION. The Products are protected by copyright and other intellectual property laws and by international treaties. We acknowledge and agree that we are not acquiring title to any intellectual property rights in the Products and that full title and all ownership rights to the Products will remain the exclusive property of CIS or CIS Parties. CIS reserves all rights not expressly granted to users in the preceding section entitled "Grant of limited rights." Subject to the paragraph entitled "Special Rules" (which includes a waiver, granted to some classes of CIS Members, of certain limitations in this paragraph), and except as we may have otherwise agreed in a written agreement with CIS, we agree that we will not (i) decompile, disassemble, reverse engineer, or otherwise attempt to derive the source code for any software Product that is not already in the form of source code; (ii) distribute, redistribute, encumber, sell, rent, lease, lend, sublicense, or otherwise transfer or exploit rights to any Product or any component of a Product; (iii) post any Product or any component of a Product on any website, bulletin board, ftp server, newsgroup, or other similar mechanism or device, without regard to whether such mechanism or device is internal or external, (iv) remove or alter trademark, logo, copyright or other proprietary notices, legends, symbols or labels in any Product or any component of a Product; (v) remove these Agreed Terms of Use from, or alter these Agreed Terms of Use as they appear in, any Product or any component of a Product; (vi) use any Product or any component of a Product with any derivative works based directly on a Product or any component of a Product; (vii) use any Product or any component of a Product with other products or applications that are directly and specifically dependent on such Product or any component for any part of their functionality, or (viii) represent or claim a particular level of compliance with a CIS Benchmark, scoring tool or other Product. We hereby agree to indemnify, defend, and hold CIS and all of its officers, directors, members, contributors, employees, authors, developers, agents, affiliates, licensors, information and service providers, software suppliers, hardware suppliers, and all other persons who aided CIS in the creation, development, or maintenance of the Products or Recommendations ("CIS Parties") harmless from and against any and all liability, losses, costs, and expenses (including attorneys' fees and court costs) incurred by CIS or any CIS Party in connection with any claim arising out of any violation by us of the preceding paragraph, including without limitation CIS's right, at our expense, to assume the exclusive defense and control of any matter subject to this indemnification, and in such case, we agree to cooperate with CIS in its defense of such claim. xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Items in this profile apply to Oracle Database 12c configured to use Traditional Auditing and intend to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Be practical and prudent;
Provide a clear security benefit; and
Not inhibit the utility of the technology beyond acceptable means.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Oracle Database Installation and Patching Requirements

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: One of the best ways to ensure secure Oracle security is to implement Critical Patch Updates (CPUs) as they come out, along with any applicable OS patches that will not interfere with system operations. It is additionally prudent to remove Oracle sample data from production environments.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure the Appropriate Version/Patches for Oracle Software Is Installed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Oracle installation version and patches should be the most recent that are compatible with the organization's operational needs.

controls:control.title: Inventory of Authorized and Unauthorized Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using the most recent Oracle database software, along with all applicable patches can help limit the possibilities for vulnerabilities in the software, the installation version and/or patches applied during setup should be established according to the needs of the organization. Ensure you are using a release that is covered by a level of support that includes the generation of Critical Patch Updates.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Perform the following step for remediation:
Download and apply the latest quarterly Critical Patch Update patches.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure All Default Passwords Are Changed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Default passwords should not be used by Oracle database users.

controls:safeguard.title: Change Default Passwords On All New Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Default passwords should be considered "well known" to attackers. Consequently, if default passwords remain in place, any attacker with access to the database can authenticate as the user with that default password.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation, you may perform either of the following actions:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Manually issue the following SQL statement for each USERNAME returned in the Audit Procedure:

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure All Sample Data And Users Have Been Removed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
Oracle sample schemas can be used to create sample users ( BI
, HR
, IX
, OE
, PM
, SCOTT
, SH
), with well-known default passwords, particular views, and procedures/functions, in addition to tables and fictitious data. The sample schemas should be removed.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Deployed Software Of Development Artifacts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The sample schemas are typically not required for production operations of the database. The default users, views, and/or procedures/functions created by sample schemas could be used to launch exploits against production environments.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL script.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: $ORACLE_HOME/demo/schema/drop_sch.sql
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Then, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: DROP USER SCOTT CASCADE;
xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
The recyclebin
is not set to OFF
within the default drop script, which means that the data will still be present in your environment until the recyclebin
is emptied.
Impact:

The Oracle sample usernames may be in use on a production basis. It is important that you first verify that BI
, HR
, IX
, OE
, PM
, SCOTT
, and/or SH
are not valid production usernames before executing the dropping SQL scripts. This may be particularly true with the HR
and BI
users. If any of these users are present, it is important to be cautious and confirm the schemas present are, in fact, Oracle sample schemas and not production schemas being relied upon by business operations.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The operation of the Oracle database instance is governed by numerous parameters that are set in specific configuration files and are instance-specific in scope. As alterations of these parameters can cause problems ranging from denial-of-service to theft of proprietary information, these configurations should be carefully considered and maintained.

Note:
For all files that have parameters that can be modified with the OS and/or SQL commands/scripts, these will both be listed where appropriate.

This section defines recommendations for the settings for the TNS Listener listener.ora
file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SECURE_CONTROL_<listener_name>' Is Set In 'listener.ora'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The SECURE_CONTROL_<listener_name> setting determines the type of control connection the Oracle server requires for remote configuration of the listener.

controls:safeguard.title: Use Only Secure Channels For Remote System Administration

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Listener configuration changes via unencrypted remote connections can result in unauthorized users sniffing control configuration information from the network.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation:

Set the SECURE_CONTROL_<listener_name> for each defined listener in the listener.ora
file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'extproc' Is Not Present in 'listener.ora'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
extproc
should be removed from the listener.ora
to mitigate the risk that OS libraries can be invoked by the Oracle instance.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Deployed Software Of Development Artifacts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
extproc
allows the database to run procedures from OS libraries. These library calls can, in turn, run any OS command.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation:

Remove extproc
from the listener.ora
file.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ADMIN_RESTRICTIONS_<listener_name>' Is Set to 'ON'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The admin_restrictions_<listener_name> setting in the listener.ora
file can require that any attempted real-time alteration of the parameters in the listener
via the set
command file be refused unless the listener.ora
file is manually altered, then restarted by a privileged user.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Blocking unprivileged users from making alterations of the listener.ora
file, where remote data/service settings are specified, will help protect data confidentiality.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation:

Use a text editor such as vi
to set the admin_restrictions_<listener_name> to the value ON
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SECURE_REGISTER_<listener_name>' Is Set to 'TCPS' or 'IPC'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SECURE_REGISTER_<listener_name> setting specifies the protocols used to connect to the TNS listener. Each setting should have a value of either TCPS
or IPC
based on the needs for its protocol.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt All Sensitive Information Over Less-trusted Networks

notes:notes.xhtml:p: Oracle Real Application Cluster requires a different approach to fix the TNS Poisoning problem. See Oracle support note 1453883.1 for details.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Listener configuration changes via unencrypted remote connections can result in unauthorized users sniffing control configuration information from the network.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation:

Use a text editor such as vi
to set the SECURE_REGISTER_<listener_name>=TCPS or SECURE_REGISTER_<listener_name>=IPC for each listener found in $ORACLE_HOME/network/admin/listener.ora
.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section defines recommendations covering the general security configuration of the database instance. The recommendations ensure auditing is enabled, listeners are appropriately confined, and authentication is appropriately configured.

Note:
The remediation procedures assume the use of a server parameter file, which is often a preferred method of storing server initialization parameters.

For your environment, leaving off the SCOPE = SPFILE
directive or substituting it with SCOPE = BOTH
might be preferred depending on the recommendation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AUDIT_SYS_OPERATIONS' Is Set to 'TRUE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The AUDIT_SYS_OPERATIONS
setting provides for the auditing of all user activities conducted under the SYSOPER
and SYSDBA
accounts. The setting should be set to TRUE
to enable this auditing.

controls:safeguard.title: Log Administrative User Addition And Removal
Ensure Audit Log Settings Support Appropriate Log Entry Formatting

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
If the parameter AUDIT_SYS_OPERATIONS
is FALSE
, all statements except for Startup/Shutdown and Logon by SYSDBA
/ SYSOPER
users are not audited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_SYS_OPERATIONS = TRUE SCOPE=SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AUDIT_TRAIL' Is Set to 'DB', 'XML', 'OS', 'DB,EXTENDED', or 'XML,EXTENDED'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The audit_trail
setting determines whether or not Oracle's basic audit features are enabled. It can be set to "Operating System"( OS
); DB
; DB,EXTENDED
; XML
; or XML,EXTENDED
. The value should be set according to the needs of the organization.

controls:control.title: Maintenance, Monitoring, and Analysis of Audit Logs

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling the basic auditing features for the Oracle instance permits the collection of data to troubleshoot problems, as well as provides valuable forensic logs in the case of a system breach this value should be set according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute one of the following SQL statements.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_TRAIL = DB, EXTENDED SCOPE = SPFILE;
ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_TRAIL = OS SCOPE = SPFILE;
ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_TRAIL = XML, EXTENDED SCOPE = SPFILE;
ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_TRAIL = DB SCOPE = SPFILE;
ALTER SYSTEM SET AUDIT_TRAIL = XML SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'GLOBAL_NAMES' Is Set to 'TRUE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The global_names
setting requires that the name of a database link matches that of the remote database it will connect to. This setting should have a value of TRUE
.

controls:control.title: Limitation and Control of Network Ports, Protocols, and Services

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Not requiring database connections to match the domain that is being called remotely could allow unauthorized domain sources to potentially connect via brute-force tactics.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET GLOBAL_NAMES = TRUE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'O7_DICTIONARY_ACCESSIBILITY' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The O7_dictionary_accessibility
setting is a database initialization parameter that allows/disallows access to objects with the * ANY *
privileges ( SELECT ANY TABLE
, DELETE ANY TABLE
, EXECUTE ANY PROCEDURE
, etc.). This functionality was created for the ease of migration from Oracle 7 databases to later versions. The setting should have a value of FALSE
.

controls:safeguard.title: Limit Open Ports, Protocols, and Services

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The value for this is "O(oh)7" not "0(Zero)7" for O7
. Also, for "Oracle Applications" up to version 11.5.9, this setting is reversed; the O7_dictionary_accessibility=TRUE
value is required for correct operations.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Leaving the SYS
schema so open to connection could permit unauthorized access to critical data structures.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET O7_DICTIONARY_ACCESSIBILITY=FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'OS_ROLES' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The os_roles
setting permits externally created groups to be applied to database management.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing the OS to use external groups for database management could cause privilege overlaps and generally weaken security.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET OS_ROLES = FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'REMOTE_LISTENER' Is Empty

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The remote_listener
setting determines whether or not a valid listener can be established on a system separate from the database instance. This setting should be empty unless the organization specifically needs a valid listener on a separate system.

controls:control.title: Limitation and Control of Network Ports, Protocols, and Services

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
If set as remote_listener=true
, the address/address list is taken from the TNSNAMES.ORA
file.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permitting a remote listener for connections to the database instance can allow for the potential spoofing of connections and that could compromise data confidentiality and integrity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET REMOTE_LISTENER = '' SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE' Is Set to 'NONE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The remote_login_passwordfile
setting specifies whether or not Oracle checks for a password file during login and how many databases can use the password file. The setting should have a value of NONE
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The use of this sort of password login file could permit unsecured, privileged connections to the database.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE = 'NONE' SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The remote_os_authent
setting determines whether or not OS 'roles' with the attendant privileges are allowed for remote client connections. This setting should have a value of FALSE
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permitting OS roles for database connections to can allow the spoofing of connections and permit granting the privileges of an OS role to unauthorized users to make connections, this value should be restricted according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT = FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'REMOTE_OS_ROLES' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The remote_os_roles
setting permits remote users' OS roles to be applied to database management. This setting should have a value of FALSE
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing remote clients OS roles to have permissions for database management could cause privilege overlaps and generally weaken security.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET REMOTE_OS_ROLES = FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'UTL_FILE_DIR' Is Empty

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The utl_file_dir
setting allows packages like utl_file
to access (read/write/modify/delete) files specified in utl_file_dir
. This setting should have an empty value.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Using the utl_file_dir
to create directories allows the manipulation of files in these directories.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET UTL_FILE_DIR = '' SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SEC_CASE_SENSITIVE_LOGON' Is Set to 'TRUE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SEC_CASE_SENSITIVE_LOGON
information determines whether or not case-sensitivity is required for passwords during login.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Oracle database password case-sensitivity increases the pool of characters that can be chosen for the passwords, making brute-force password attacks quite difficult.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SEC_CASE_SENSITIVE_LOGON = TRUE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS' Is '3' or Less

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS
parameter determines how many failed login attempts are allowed before Oracle closes the login connection.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Account Lockouts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing an unlimited number of login attempts for a user connection can facilitate both brute-force login attacks and the occurrence of denial-of-service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS = 3 SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_FURTHER_ACTION' Is Set to 'DROP,3'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_FURTHER_ACTION
setting determines the Oracle's server's response to bad/malformed packets received from the client. This setting should have a value of DROP,3
, which will cause a connection to be dropped after three bad/malformed packets.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Bad packets received from the client can potentially indicate packet-based attacks on the system, such as "TCP SYN Flood" or "Smurf" attacks, which could result in a denial-of-service condition, this value should be set according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute one of the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_FURTHER_ACTION = 'DROP,3' SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_TRACE_ACTION' Is Set to 'LOG'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_TRACE_ACTION
setting determines the Oracle's server's logging response level to bad/malformed packets received from the client by generating ALERT
, LOG
, or TRACE
levels of detail in the log files. This setting should have a value of LOG
unless the organization has a compelling reason to use a different value because LOG
should cause the necessary information to be logged. Setting the value as TRACE
can generate an enormous amount of log output and should be reserved for debugging only.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Audit Log Settings Support Appropriate Log Entry Formatting

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Bad packets received from the client can potentially indicate packet-based attacks on the system, which could result in a denial-of-service condition.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SEC_PROTOCOL_ERROR_TRACE_ACTION=LOG SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SEC_RETURN_SERVER_RELEASE_BANNER' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The information about patch/update release number provides information about the exact patch/update release that is currently running on the database. This is sensitive information that should not be revealed to anyone who requests it.

controls:control.title: Limitation and Control of Network Ports, Protocols, and Services

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing the database to return information about the patch/update release number could facilitate unauthorized users' attempts to gain access based upon known patch weaknesses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SEC_RETURN_SERVER_RELEASE_BANNER = FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SQL92_SECURITY' Is Set to 'TRUE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SQL92_SECURITY
parameter setting TRUE
requires that a user must also be granted the SELECT
object privilege before being able to perform UPDATE
or DELETE
operations on tables that have WHERE
or SET
clauses. The setting should have a value of TRUE.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
A user without SELECT
privilege can still infer the value stored in a column by referring to that column in a DELETE
or UPDATE
statement. This setting prevents inadvertent information disclosure by ensuring that only users who already have SELECT
privilege can execute the statements that would allow them to infer the stored values.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET SQL92_SECURITY = TRUE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure '_trace_files_public' Is Set to 'FALSE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The _trace_files_public
setting determines whether or not the system's trace file is world readable. This setting should have a value of FALSE to restrict trace file access.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information With Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Making the file world readable means anyone can read the instance's trace file, which could contain sensitive information about instance operations.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET "_trace_files_public" = FALSE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RESOURCE_LIMIT' Is Set to 'TRUE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
RESOURCE_LIMIT
determines whether resource limits are enforced in database profiles. This setting should have a value of TRUE
.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information With Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
If RESOURCE_LIMIT
is set to FALSE
, none of the system resource limits that are set in any database profiles are enforced. If RESOURCE_LIMIT
is set to TRUE
, the limits set in database profiles are enforced.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: ALTER SYSTEM SET RESOURCE_LIMIT = TRUE SCOPE = SPFILE;

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The restrictions on Client/User connections to the Oracle database help block unauthorized access to data and services by setting access rules. These security measures help to ensure that successful logins cannot be easily made through brute-force password attacks or intuited by clever social engineering exploits. Settings are generally recommended to be applied to all defined profiles rather than by using only the DEFAULT
profile. All values assigned below are the recommended minimums or maximums; higher, more restrictive values can be applied at the discretion of the organization by creating a separate profile to assign to a different user group.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS' Is Less than or Equal to '5'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS
setting determines how many failed login attempts are permitted before the system locks the user's account. While different profiles can have different and more restrictive settings, such as USERS
and APPS
, the minimum(s) recommended here should be set on the DEFAULT
profile.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Account Lockouts

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
Warning:
One great concern with the above is the possibility of this setting being exploited to craft a DDoS attack by using the row-locking delay between failed login attempts (see _Oracle Bug 7715339 – Logon failures causes “row cache lock” waits – Allow disable of logon delay [ID 7715339.8], so the configuration of this setting depends on using the bug workaround). Also, while the setting for the FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS
value can also be set in sqlnet.ora
, this only applies to listed users. The similar setting used to block a DDoS, the SEC_MAX_FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS
initialization parameter, can be used to protect unauthorized intruders from attacking the server processes for applications, but this setting does not protect against unauthorized attempts via valid usernames.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Repeated failed login attempts can indicate the initiation of a brute-force login attack, this value should be set according to the needs of the organization. (See the Notes
for a warning on a known bug that can make this security measure backfire.)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME' Is Greater than or Equal to '1'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME
setting determines how many days must pass for the user's account to be unlocked after the set number of failed login attempts has occurred. The suggested value for this is one day or greater.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Account Lockouts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Locking the user account after repeated failed login attempts can block further brute-force login attacks, but can create administrative headaches as this account unlocking process always requires DBA intervention.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME' Is Less than or Equal to '90'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_LIFE_TIME
setting determines how long a password may be used before the user is required to be change it. The suggested value for this is 90 days or less.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing passwords to remain unchanged for long periods makes the success of brute-force login attacks more likely.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX' Is Greater than or Equal to '20'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX
setting determines how many different passwords must be used before the user is allowed to reuse a prior password. The suggested value for this is 20 passwords or greater.

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The above restriction should be applied along with the PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME
setting.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing reuse of a password within a short period of time after the password's initial use can make the success of both social-engineering and brute-force password-based attacks more likely.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME' Is Greater than or Equal to '365'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME
setting determines the amount of time in days that must pass before the same password may be reused. The suggested value for this is 365 days or greater.

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The above restriction should be applied along with the PASSWORD_REUSE_MAX
setting.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Reusing the same password after only a short period of time has passed makes the success of brute-force login attacks more likely.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME' Is Less than or Equal to '5'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_GRACE_TIME
setting determines how many days can pass after the user's password expires before the user's login capability is automatically locked out. The suggested value for this is five days or less.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Locking the user account after the expiration of the password change requirement's grace period can help prevent password-based attacks against any forgotten or disused accounts, while still allowing the account and its information to be accessible by DBA intervention.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Remediate this setting by executing the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DBA_USERS.PASSWORD' Is Not Set to 'EXTERNAL' for Any User

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The password='EXTERNAL'
setting determines whether or not a user can be authenticated by a remote OS to allow access to the database with full authorization. This setting should not be used.

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD
keyword (column) used in the SQL for prior Oracle versions has been deprecated from version 11.2 onward in favor of the new AUTHENTICATION_TYPE
keyword (column) for the DBA_USERS
table. However, the PASSWORD
column has still been retained for backward compatibility.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing remote OS authentication of a user to the database can potentially allow supposed "privileged users" to connect as "authenticated," even when the remote system is compromised.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PASSWORD_VERIFY_FUNCTION' Is Set for All Profiles

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The PASSWORD_VERIFY_FUNCTION
determines password settings requirements when a user password is changed at the SQL command prompt. It should be set for all profiles. Note that this setting does not apply for users managed by the Oracle password file.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Requiring users to apply the 12c security features in password creation, such as forcing mixed-case complexity, blocking of simple combinations, and enforcing change/history settings can potentially thwart logins by an unauthorized user.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create a custom password verification function which fulfills the password requirements of the organization.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SESSIONS_PER_USER' Is Less than or Equal to '10'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The SESSIONS_PER_USER
setting determines the maximum number of user sessions that are allowed to be open concurrently. The suggested value for this is 10 or less.

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The SESSIONS_PER_USER
profile management capability was created to prevent resource(s) exhaustion at a time when resource usage was very expensive. As current database design may require much higher limits on this parameter if one "user" handles all processing for specific types of batch/customer connections, this must be handled via a new user profile.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Limiting the number of the SESSIONS_PER_USER
can help prevent memory resource exhaustion by poorly formed requests or intentional denial-of-service attacks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement for each PROFILE
returned by the audit procedure.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure No Users Are Assigned the 'DEFAULT' Profile

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
Upon creation database users are assigned to the DEFAULT
profile unless otherwise specified. No users should be assigned to that profile.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Users should be created with function-appropriate profiles. The DEFAULT
profile, being defined by Oracle, is subject to change at any time (e.g. by patch or version update). The DEFAULT
profile has unlimited settings that are often required by the SYS
user when patching; such unlimited settings should be tightly reserved and not applied to unnecessary users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this recommendation, execute the following SQL statement for each user returned by the audit query using a functional-appropriate profile.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Oracle User Access and Authorization Restrictions

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The capability to use database resources at a given level, or user authorization rules, allows for user manipulation of the various parts of the Oracle database. These authorizations must be structured to block unauthorized use and/or corruption of vital data and services by setting restrictions on user capabilities, particularly those of the user PUBLIC
. Such security measures help to ensure successful logins cannot be easily redirected.

IMPORTANT:
Use caution when revoking privileges from PUBLIC
. Oracle and third-party products explicitly require default grants to PUBLIC
for commonly used functions, objects, and in view definitions. After revoking any privilege from PUBLIC
, verify that applications keep running properly and recompile invalid database objects. Specific grants to users and roles may be needed to make all objects valid. Please see the following Oracle support document which provides further information and SQL statements that can be used to determine dependencies that require explicit grants: Be Cautious When Revoking Privileges Granted to PUBLIC
(Doc ID 247093.1) Always test database changes in development and test environments before making changes to production databases.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Default Public Privileges for Packages and Object Types

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that revoke default public execute privileges from powerful packages and object types.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_ADVISOR'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_ADVISOR
package can be used to write files located on the server where the Oracle instance is installed. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_ADVISOR
.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_ADVISOR
package could allow an unauthorized user to corrupt operating system files on the instance's host.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_ADVISOR FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_CRYPTO'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_CRYPTO
settings provide a toolset that determines the strength of the encryption algorithm used to encrypt application data and is part of the SYS
schema. The DES
(56-bit key), 3DES
(168-bit key), 3DES-2KEY
(112-bit key), AES
(128/192/256-bit keys), and RC4
are available. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_CRYPTO
.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Execution of these cryptography procedures by the user PUBLIC
can potentially endanger portions of or all of the data storage.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_CRYPTO FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_JAVA'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_JAVA
package can run Java classes (e.g. OS commands) or grant Java privileges. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_JAVA
.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Deployed Software Of Development Artifacts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_JAVA
package could allow an attacker to run OS commands from the database.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_JAVA FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_JAVA_TEST'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_JAVA_TEST
package can run Java classes (e.g. OS commands) or grant Java privileges. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_JAVA_TEST
.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Deployed Software Of Development Artifacts

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
DBMS_JAVA_TEST
is an undocumented PL/SQL package, but the public grant should be revoked.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_JAVA_TEST
package could allow an attacker to run operating system commands from the database.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_JAVA_TEST FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_JOB'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_JOB
package schedules and manages the jobs sent to the job queue and has been superseded by the DBMS_SCHEDULER
package, even though DBMS_JOB
has been retained for backwards compatibility. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_JOB
.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_JOB
package could allow an unauthorized user to disable or overload the job queue. It has been superseded by the DBMS_SCHEDULER
package.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_JOB FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_LDAP'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_LDAP
package contains functions and procedures that enable programmers to access data from LDAP servers. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_LDAP
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_LDAP
package can be used to create specially crafted error messages or send information via DNS to the outside.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_LDAP FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_LOB'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_LOB
package provides subprograms that can manipulate and read/write on BLOBs
, CLOBs
, NCLOBs
, BFILEs
, and temporary LOBs
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_LOB
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_LOB
package could allow an unauthorized user to manipulate BLOBs
, CLOBs
, NCLOBs
, BFILEs
, and temporary LOBs
on the instance, either destroying data or causing a denial-of-service condition due to corruption of disk space.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_LOB FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT
provides one of the tools that determine the strength of the encryption algorithm used to encrypt application data and is part of the SYS
schema. The DES
(56-bit key) and 3DES
(168-bit key) are the only two types available. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT
.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Allowing the PUBLIC
user privileges to access this capability can be potentially harm data storage.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_OBFUSCATION_TOOLKIT FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_RANDOM'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_RANDOM
package is used for generating random numbers but should not be used for cryptographic purposes. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_RANDOM
.

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
The OEM cautions that removing this from PUBLIC
may break certain applications.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_RANDOM
package can allow the unauthorized application of the random number-generating function.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_RANDOM FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_SCHEDULER'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_SCHEDULER
package schedules and manages the database and operating system jobs. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_SCHEDULER
.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Use of the DBMS_SCHEDULER
package could allow an unauthorized user to run database or operating system jobs.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_SCHEDULER FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_SQL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_SQL
package is used for running dynamic SQL statements. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_SQL
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_SQL
package could allow privilege escalation if input validation is not done properly.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_SQL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_XMLGEN'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_XMLGEN
package takes an arbitrary SQL query as input, converts it to XML format, and returns the result as a CLOB
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_XMLGEN
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The package DBMS_XMLGEN
can be used to search the entire database for sensitive information like credit card numbers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_XMLGEN FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_XMLQUERY'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle package DBMS_XMLQUERY
takes an arbitrary SQL query, converts it to XML format, and returns the result. This package is similar to DBMS_XMLGEN
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_XMLQUERY
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The package DBMS_XMLQUERY
can be used to search the entire database for sensitive information like credit card numbers. Malicious users may be able to exploit this package as an auxiliary inject function in a SQL injection attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_XMLQUERY FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_FILE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_FILE
package can be used to read/write files located on the server where the Oracle instance is installed. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_FILE
.

controls:control.title: Controlled Access Based on the Need to Know

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_FILE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_INADDR'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_INADDR
package can be used to create specially crafted error messages or send information via DNS to the outside. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_INADDR
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_INADDR
package is often used in SQL injection attacks from the web it should be revoked from public.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_INADDR FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_TCP'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_TCP
package can be used to read/write file to TCP sockets on the server where the Oracle instance is installed. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_TCP
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_TCP
package could allow an unauthorized user to corrupt the TCP stream used to carry the protocols that communicate with the instance's external communications.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_TCP FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_MAIL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_MAIL
package can be used to send email from the server where the Oracle instance is installed. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_MAIL
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_MAIL
package could allow an unauthorized user to corrupt the SMTP function to accept or generate junk mail that can result in a denial-of-service condition due to network saturation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_MAIL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_SMTP'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_SMTP
package can be used to send email from the server where the Oracle instance is installed. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_SMTP
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_SMTP
package could allow an unauthorized user to corrupt the SMTP function to accept or generate junk mail that can result in a denial-of-service condition due to network saturation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_SMTP FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_DBWS'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_DBWS
package can be used to read/write file to web-based applications on the server where the Oracle instance is installed. This package is not automatically installed for security reasons. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_DBWS
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_DBWS
package could allow an unauthorized user to corrupt the HTTP stream used to carry the protocols that communicate for the instance's web-based external communications.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_DBWS FROM 'PUBLIC';

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_ORAMTS'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_ORAMTS
package can be used to perform HTTP requests. This could be used to send information to the outside. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_ORAMTS
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_ORAMTS
package could be used to send (sensitive) information to external websites. The use of this package should be restricted according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_ORAMTS FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'UTL_HTTP'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database UTL_HTTP
package can be used to perform HTTP requests. This could be used to send information to the outside. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute UTL_HTTP
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The UTL_HTTP
package could be used to send (sensitive) information to external websites. The use of this package should be restricted according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON UTL_HTTP FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'HTTPURITYPE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database HTTPURITYPE
object type can be used to perform HTTP requests. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute HTTPURITYPE
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The ability to perform HTTP requests could be used to leak information from the database to an external destination.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON HTTPURITYPE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' is revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_XMLSTORE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_XLMSTORE
package provides XML functionality. It accepts a table name and XML as input to perform DML operations against the table. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_XLMSTORE
.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Input For In-house Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious users may be able to exploit this package as an auxiliary inject function in a SQL injection attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_XMLSTORE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' is revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_XMLSAVE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_XLMSTORE
package provides XML functionality. It accepts a table name and XML as input and then inserts into or updates that table. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_XLMSAVE
.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Input For In-house Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious users may be able to exploit this package as an auxiliary inject function in a SQL injection attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_XMLSAVE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' is revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_REDACT'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_REDACT
package provides an interface to Oracle Data Redaction, which enables you to mask (redact) data that is returned from queries issued by low-privileged users or an application. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_REDACT
.

controls:safeguard.title: Sanitize Input For In-house Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious users may be able to exploit this package as an auxiliary inject function in a SQL injection attack.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_REDACT FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Revoke Non-Default Privileges for Packages and Object Types

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommendations within this section revoke excessive privileges for packages and object types.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_SYS_SQL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_SYS_SQL
package is shipped as undocumented. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_SYS_SQL
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_SYS_SQL
package could allow an user to run code as a different user without entering valid credentials.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_SYS_SQL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE
package is used for applying PL/SQL commands to the native RMAN
sequences. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE
package can allow access to OS files.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_BACKUP_RESTORE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS
package is shipped as undocumented. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_AQADM_SYSCALLS FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: revoke execute on DBMS_REPCAT_SQL_UTL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'INITJVMAUX'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database INITJVMAUX
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute INITJVMAUX
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The INITJVMAUX
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON INITJVMAUX FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_STREAMS_ADM_UTL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_AQADM_SYS'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_AQADM_SYS
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_AQADM_SYS
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_AQADM_SYS
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_AQADM_SYS FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_STREAMS_RPC'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_STREAMS_RPC
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS
. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_STREAMS_RPC
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_STREAMS_RPC
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL commands as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_STREAMS_RPC FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_PRVTAQIM'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_PRVTAQIM
package is shipped as undocumented and allows to run SQL commands as user SYS. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_PRVTAQIM
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_PRVTAQIM
package could allow an unauthorized user to escalate privileges because any SQL statements could be executed as user SYS.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_PRVTAQIM FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'LTADM'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database LTADM
package is shipped as undocumented. It allows privilege escalation if granted to unprivileged users. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute LTADM
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The LTADM
package could allow an unauthorized user to run any SQL command as user SYS
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON LTADM FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'WWV_DBMS_SQL'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database WWV_DBMS_SQL
package is shipped as undocumented. It allows Oracle Application Express to run dynamic SQL statements.

controls:control.title: Controlled Access Based on the Need to Know

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The WWV_DBMS_SQL
package could allow an unauthorized user to run SQL statements as the Application Express ( APEX
) user. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute WWV_DBMS_SQL
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON WWV_DBMS_SQL FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'WWV_EXECUTE_IMMEDIATE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database WWV_EXECUTE_IMMEDIATE
package is shipped as undocumented. It allows Oracle Application Express to run dynamic SQL statements. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute WWV_EXECUTE_IMMEDIATE
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON WWV_EXECUTE_IMMEDIATE FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_IJOB'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_IJOB
package is shipped as undocumented. It allows a user to run database jobs in the context of another user. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_IJOB
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_IJOB
package could allow an attacker to change identities by using a different username to execute a database job.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_IJOB FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE' Is Revoked from 'PUBLIC' on 'DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER
package allows a user to transfer files from one database server to another. The user PUBLIC
should not be able to execute DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER
package could allow to transfer files from one database server to another without authorization to do so.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: REVOKE EXECUTE ON DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER FROM PUBLIC;

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommendations within this section revoke excessive system privileges.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SELECT ANY DICTIONARY' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SELECT ANY DICTIONARY
privilege allows the designated user to access SYS
schema objects. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information With Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The Oracle password hashes are part of the SYS
schema and can be selected using SELECT ANY DICTIONARY
privileges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SELECT ANY TABLE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SELECT ANY TABLE
privilege allows the designated user to open any table, except SYS
, to view it. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information With Access Control Lists

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
If O7_DICTIONARY_ACCESSIBILITY
has been set to TRUE
(non-default setting) then the SELECT ANY TABLE
privilege provides access to SYS
objects.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Assignment of the SELECT ANY TABLE
privilege can allow the unauthorized viewing of sensitive data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AUDIT SYSTEM' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database AUDIT SYSTEM
privilege allows changes to auditing activities on the system. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The AUDIT SYSTEM
privilege can allow the unauthorized alteration of system audit activities, such as disabling the creation of audit trails.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY
keyword provides the user the capability to access all the table rows regardless of row-level security lockouts. Unauthorized grantees should not have that keyword assigned to them.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information With Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The EXEMPT ACCESS POLICY
privilege can allow an unauthorized user to potentially access and change data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'BECOME USER' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database BECOME USER
privilege allows the designated user to inherit the rights of another user. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The BECOME USER
privilege can allow the unauthorized use of another user's privileges, this capability should be restricted according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CREATE_PROCEDURE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database CREATE PROCEDURE
privilege allows the designated user to create a stored procedure that will fire when given the correct command sequence. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The CREATE PROCEDURE
privilege can lead to severe problems in unauthorized hands, such as rogue procedures facilitating data theft or denial-of-service by corrupting data tables.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALTER SYSTEM' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database ALTER SYSTEM
privilege allows the designated user to dynamically alter the instance's running operations. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The ALTER SYSTEM
privilege can lead to severe problems, such as the instance's session being killed or the stopping of redo log recording, which would make transactions unrecoverable.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CREATE ANY LIBRARY' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database CREATE ANY LIBRARY
privilege allows the designated user to create objects that are associated to the shared libraries. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
Oracle has two identical privileges: CREATE LIBRARY
and CREATE ANY LIBRARY
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The CREATE ANY LIBRARY
privilege can allow the creation of numerous library-associated objects and potentially corrupt the libraries' integrity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CREATE LIBRARY' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database CREATE LIBRARY
privilege allows the designated user to create objects that are associated to the shared libraries. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
Oracle has two identical privileges: CREATE LIBRARY
and CREATE ANY LIBRARY
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The CREATE LIBRARY
privilege can allow the creation of numerous library-associated objects and potentially corrupt the libraries' integrity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'GRANT ANY OBJECT PRIVILEGE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database GRANT ANY OBJECT PRIVILEGE
keyword provides the grantee the capability to grant access to any single or multiple combinations of objects to any grantee in the catalog of the database. Unauthorized grantees should not have that keyword assigned to them.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The GRANT ANY OBJECT PRIVILEGE
capability can allow an unauthorized user to potentially access or change confidential data, or damage the data catalog due to potential complete instance access.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'GRANT ANY ROLE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database GRANT ANY ROLE
keyword provides the grantee the capability to grant any single role to any grantee in the catalog of the database. Unauthorized grantees should not have that keyword assigned to them.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The GRANT ANY ROLE
capability can allow an unauthorized user to potentially access or change confidential data or damage the data catalog due to potential complete instance access.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'GRANT ANY PRIVILEGE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database GRANT ANY PRIVILEGE
keyword provides the grantee the capability to grant any single privilege to any item in the catalog of the database. Unauthorized grantees should not have that privilege.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The GRANT ANY PRIVILEGE
capability can allow an unauthorized user to potentially access or change confidential data or damage the data catalog due to potential complete instance access.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommendations within this section intend to revoke powerful roles where they are likely not needed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE
provides DELETE
privileges for the records in the system's audit table ( AUD$
). Unauthorized grantees should not have that role.

controls:control.title: Maintenance, Monitoring, and Analysis of Audit Logs

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting unauthorized access to the DELETE_CATALOG_ROLE
can allow the destruction of audit records vital to the forensic investigation of unauthorized activities.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE
provides SELECT
privileges on all data dictionary views held in the SYS
schema. Unauthorized grantees should not have that role.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting unauthorized access to the SELECT_CATALOG_ROLE
can allow the disclosure of all dictionary data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE
provides EXECUTE
privileges for a number of packages and procedures in the data dictionary in the SYS
schema. Unauthorized grantees should not have that role.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting unauthorized access to the EXECUTE_CATALOG_ROLE
can allow the disruption of operations by initialization of rogue procedures, this capability should be restricted according to the needs of the organization.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DBA' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBA
role is the default database administrator role provided for the allocation of administrative privileges. Unauthorized grantees should not have that role.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Assignment of the DBA
role to an ordinary user can provide a great number of unnecessary privileges to that user and open the door to data breaches, integrity violations, and denial-of-service conditions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Group.xccdf:title: Revoke Excessive Table and View Privileges

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommendations within this section intend to revoke excessive table and view privileges.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALL' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE' on 'AUD$'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SYS.AUD$
table contains all the audit records for the database of the non-Data Manipulation Language (DML) events, such as ALTER
, DROP
, and CREATE
, and so forth. (DML changes need trigger-based audit events to record data alterations.) Unauthorized grantees should not have full access to that table.

controls:control.title: Maintenance, Monitoring, and Analysis of Audit Logs

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting non-privileged users the authorization to manipulate the SYS.AUD$
table can allow distortion of the audit records, hiding unauthorized activities.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALL' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE' on 'USER_HISTORY$'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SYS.USER_HISTORY$
table contains all the audit records for the user's password change history. (This table gets updated by password changes if the user has an assigned profile that has a password reuse limit set, e.g., PASSWORD_REUSE_TIME
set to other than UNLIMITED
.) Unauthorized grantees should not have full access to that table.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges
Encrypt/Hash All Authentication Files And Monitor Their Access

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
USER_HISTORY$
contains only the old, case-insensitive passwords.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting non-privileged users the authorization to manipulate the records in the SYS.USER_HISTORY$
table can allow distortion of the audit trail, potentially hiding unauthorized data confidentiality attacks or integrity changes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALL' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE' on 'LINK$'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SYS.LINK$
table contains all the user's password information and data table link information. Unauthorized grantees should not have full access to that table.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges
Encrypt/Hash All Authentication Files And Monitor Their Access

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting non-privileged users to manipulate or view the SYS.LINK$
table can allow capture of password information and/or corrupt the primary database linkages.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALL' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE' on 'SYS.USER$'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database SYS.USER$
table contains the users' hashed password information. Unauthorized grantees should not have full access to that table.

controls:safeguard.title: Minimize And Sparingly Use Administrative Privileges
Encrypt/Hash All Authentication Files And Monitor Their Access

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Permitting non-privileged users the authorization to open the SYS.USER$
table can allow the capture of password hashes for the later application of password cracking algorithms to breach confidentiality.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To remediate this setting, execute the following SQL statement.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ALL' Is Revoked from Unauthorized 'GRANTEE' on 'DBA_%'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Oracle database DBA_
